data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Of, relating to, or characteristic of a major city.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: crowded metropolitan streets; a metropolitan newspaper.

data.text: Of or constituting a large city or urbanized area, including adjacent suburbs and towns.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: the Dallas–Fort Worth metropolitan area; a metropolitan county.

data.text: Of, relating to, or constituting the home territory of an imperial or colonial state.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Of or relating to an ecclesiastical metropolitan.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A citizen of a metropolis, especially one who displays urbane characteristics, attitudes, and values.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: In the Western Christian churches, a bishop with provincial powers, with some authority over suffragan bishops.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: In most Eastern Orthodox churches, a bishop who is head of an ecclesiastical province and ranks next below the patriarch.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: In the Greek Orthodox church, a bishop ranking next below an archbishop.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
